discussion.content:
ir.scanImage() prints "Scan." then throws an exception.
And because both classes are autoclosable, both close() methods will get invoked, but in reverse oreder,
so iw.close() gets invoked, then ir.close()
and finally, the exception message is printed

so the correct answer is A

choices.D: A compilation error occurs at line n2.
choices.C: A compilation error occurs at line n1.

questions.question_text:
Given the code fragment:
List<Integer> values = Arrays.asList (1, 2, 3);
values.stream ()
.map(n -> n*2) //line n1
.peek(System.out::print) //line n2
.count();
What is the result?

discussion.content: In java 8, count() acts as a terminal operation. so values will be printed. In java 9 or above, output might not be printed as the jre can determine the number from stream directly without using peek() operation on elements.
Answer is A
no output from java 9 and more

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A. Each element is doubled and printed with peek operation, while result of count operation is ignored.
The correct answer is A.

Selected Answer: A
In java 8 answer is A
In java 9 or more answer is B
The answer is B, output might not be printed
A test.
Yes the correct answer is 246, so A is the correct option.
Ans: A

comments.content: no, Answer A is correct! copy paste the code into eclipse and be surprised ;-)

discussion.content:
The correct answer is B . when you use count() , you cant peak on the elements of the stream.

The number of elements covered by the stream source, a List, isknown and the intermediate operation, peek, does not inject intoor remove elements from the stream (as may be the case for flatMap or filter operations). Thus the count is thesize of the List and there is no need to execute the pipelineand, as a side-effect, print out the list elements.
